item.title: (Preliminary) Course schedule
item.description: Stat/CSSS 566 Spring 2019, University of Washington Main page Textbooks: Kolaczyk, Eric D. 2009. Statistical Analysis of Network Data (SAND). and Kolaczyk, Eric D. and Cs√°rdi, G. 2014. Statistical Analysis of Network Data (SANDr). Both are available as pdf from the UW Library website. Reading: Readings come from several disciplines and, as such, assume different levels of background knowledge. You’re encouraged to read as comprehensively as possible with the understanding that readings might be assuming familiarity with topics that are new to you.

item.title: Prospective students
item.description: I’m eager to work with student and postdoctoral collaborators! Thanks for your interest! If you don’t see what you’re looking for here please get in touch. Undergraduate, Masters, and visiting students The first step in the process is to take a look around my website to see the kind of work I do and see what you find interesting. Once you’ve done that, please fill out this form to get in touch.

item.title: Statistical analysis of social network data
item.description: Tentative syllabus, subject to change (Updated 17-Feb-2019) Stat/CSSS 566 Spring 2019, University of Washington Course schedule Logistics Instructor: Tyler McCormick; Email: tylermc@uw.edu; Office Hours: TBD TA: TBD Course meetings: T/Th 11:30-12:50pm (Guggenheim 218) & F 1:30-2:20 (Savery 264) Overview & objectives This course is a practical, hands-on introduction to design and analysis of social network data, set against a backdrop of theory from sociology, economics, and other disciplines. Course components & grading Component % Grade Approx 5 HWs 40 In-class presentation 15 Final project & poster 45 In-class presentation: In weeks 3-9, Tuesday lectures will present statistical methods and Thursday lectures will be student presentations of social science papers that use the method.
